text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This manual outlines policies and standards for the establishment, design, and posting of content to IRS intranet sites.
IRM 11.1.4 has been revised to incorporate new and update existing intranet standards. Sections have been reorganized and renumbered.
All Operating Divisions and Functions
Table of
Policies and Standards for Intranet Sites 11.1.4

) This section outlines policies and standards for the establishment, design, posting of content to IRS intranet sites. The officials normally responsible for an intranet site are its Executive Owner, Content Manager, and Web trator. (
) Other intranet-related policies, standards, and guidelines include: a. Technical policy is at IRM
, Managed Service for IRS Policies (

) IRWeb ( http://irweb.irs.gov) is to be the default intranet home page for all employees. Managers who want their employees to make extensive use of Default Home different site can have employees set up a “favorite” for that site in their web browser. (

) All IRS intranet sites and servers must be registered. To register a site or server, use the online registration system ( http://wspo.web.irs.gov/webreg/ and enter.asp) maintained by Information Technology’s Enterprise Operations for Be Communications & Liaison (C&L). A site’s Content Manager, the single responsible for day-to-day management of the site, is typically the one who should complete the registration and maintain its accuracy. Most registered sites can be included in IRWeb’s directory of intranet sites and in IRWeb’s Google search index. (

) A site is any Web page, including a subweb of any registered URL, that has own home page and/or deviates from the official IRS intra-site consistency policy. All sites must secure their own registration. (

) Intra-Site Consistency Policy states a site and its subordinate pages should consistent in appearance so that users know what site they are on, which ganization owns it, and how the page fits within that site. Elements that typically be repeated throughout a site include site branding, navigation, and contact information. (

) An important component of the site registration process is the naming of the site’s Executive Owner who has ultimate responsibility for the site. The Executive Owner is to be an IRS executive or a senior manager. The embedded C&L office of applicant’s division or function must approve the Divisions or functions without a C&L staff must have their sites approved governed by Internal Communications within C&L. (

) At the conclusion of the online registration process, the system sends an to the Executive Owner to request affirmation of responsibility for the site. Executive affirmation confirms the site: (cid:
) Contains only authorized data (cid:
) Complies with mandatory system controls for Web Services (cid:
) Will adhere to the standards prescribed for all IRS intranet sites (

) Sites or servers that are not properly registered will be removed from the intranet. Additionally, loss of site registration and intranet removal will occur when a site fails to adhere to the official IRS intranet standards. Internal will alert the Executive Owner of any standards violation so that the owner take prompt action to bring the site into compliance before it is removed the system. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
(1) Other intranet-related policies, standards, and guidelines include:

All IRS intranet sites and servers must be registered. To register a site or server, use the online registration system ( http://wspo.web.irs.gov/webreg/ enter.asp) maintained by Information Technology’s Enterprise Operations for Communications & Liaison (C&L). A site’s Content Manager, the single responsible for day
to

day management of the site, is typically the one who should complete the registration and maintain its accuracy. Most registered sites can be included in IRWeb’s directory of intranet sites and in IRWeb’s Google search index.
) A site’s Executive Owner (IRS executive or senior manager appropriate for each site) is to certify that the site meets a test of business purpose. This Sites Must policy was established in a July
memorandum from the Chief C&L a Business was reaffirmed in a May
memo from the Acting Deputy Commissioner Modernization and CIO. Intranet sites with content that is frivolous or tent with achieving the business of the IRS may be pulled from the intranet. (

) IRS executives certify the business purpose of intranet sites through the registration process (all IRS intranet sites and servers must be registered). this process, a site’s Content Manager must name the Executive Owner responsible for the site’s content. At the completion of the site registration process, the system sends an email to the Executive Owner to request tion of responsibility for the site. (

) To assist executives in making this decision, it is recommended that site owners prepare and keep on file a summary of the site, its business an identification of its audience and their needs, and a brief assessment of cost to develop and maintain the site versus its expected benefit. (

) The content must be focused on the business of the IRS and must present professional appearance that would reflect well on the IRS if it were to be Content Must viewed by anyone inside or outside of the IRS. Intranet pages must not provide links to Internet sites with inappropriate content, especially those egories of sites to which access is prohibited by the IRS policy on limited personal use of IRS resources. No taxpayer data will ever be published on intranet. (
) A site’s Executive Owner should be used as the arbiter of the of the site’s content. (

) Generally, you should not post or republish content that is owned by other business units. (If you don’t own it, don’t post it.) This policy is important for the Owner of several reasons: posting someone else’s content to your site could confuse May Post It to employees about who owns the content, could mislead employees about where to get help, and — most damagingly — could give employees rate information if the true IRS owner of the content ever changes it. (

) If you want to incorporate another business or functional unit’s content into your site, the correct way to do so is by linking to it and/or by carefully rizing it and providing attribution. If the information is not already available electronically, it can be posted with permission from the content owner with attribution. (

) Only IRWeb, the IRS intranet home page, may have a search feature with scope that covers the entire intranet. The scope of search engines on other Engines Must intranet sites or applications must be limited to the content of those a Limited Scope sites. (

) Employees may not post or publish to an IRS intranet site any copyrighted material without the permission of the owner. If there is any reason to Policy that text, images, or other materials may belong to someone else, do not or otherwise use it. Link to copyrighted material, do not copy. For more mation about how to follow federal or other copyright laws, refer to: Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

memo from the Acting Deputy Commissioner Modernization and CIO. Intranet sites with content that is frivolous or inconsis- tent with achieving the business of the IRS may be pulled from the intranet. (

) IRS executives certify the business purpose of intranet sites through the site registration process (all IRS intranet sites and servers must be registered). In this process, a site’s Content Manager must name the Executive Owner who responsible for the site’s content. At the completion of the site registration process, the system sends an email to the Executive Owner to request tion of responsibility for the site. (

) To assist executives in making this decision, it is recommended that site owners prepare and keep on file a summary of the site, its business purpose, an identification of its audience and their needs, and a brief assessment of the cost to develop and maintain the site versus its expected benefit. (

) The content must be focused on the business of the IRS and must present a professional appearance that would reflect well on the IRS if it were to be Must viewed by anyone inside or outside of the IRS. Intranet pages must not provide links to Internet sites with inappropriate content, especially those cat- egories of sites to which access is prohibited by the IRS policy on limited personal use of IRS resources. No taxpayer data will ever be published on the intranet. (
) A site’s Executive Owner should be used as the arbiter of the appropriateness of the site’s content. (
) Generally, you should not post or republish content that is owned by other IRS

) IRS intranet sites and their content must be accessible. Federal and IRS requires it. The Information Resources Accessibility Program (IRAP) office Sites Must Be is responsible for setting IRS policy and standards for accessibility of content. For more information about accessibility and Section
of the bilitation Act, contact IRAP (http://irap.web.irs.gov/) or the Alternate Media Center ( http://amc.enterprise.irs.gov). Two key resources from these include IRAP’s
Accessibility Checklists, and Web Services’ Standards. (

) All IRS intranet site owners must post the IRS Privacy Policy Statement to every major entry point to the site as well as any Web page collecting Sites Must Post information from an employee. Policy (
) The notice is available at http://irweb.irs.gov/Abou
RS/irhelp/privacy/ default.aspx. (
) For more information about the requirement for privacy policy statements related issues, refer to IRM
, Inside IRS: Intranet Web Site Notices and Data Collection. You may also email questions to *Privacy. (
) The following guidelines should be followed when naming files to post to IRS intranet: Convention (cid:
) Make file names indicative of the file’s contents. (cid:
) Do not use spaces or other non-alphanumeric characters, with the exception of the hyphen – or underscore _ to show delineation in file names. (cid:
) Use of the hyphen is preferred over an underscore _ as hyphens readability for print. (cid:
) Use standard file extensions (such as .pdf for Adobe Acrobat) Limit the length of file names as much as is logical. (
) Examples of good URLs created by following basic naming conventions mentioned above: (cid:
) http://www.microsoft.com/technet/technetmag/issues/
/Wiki/default.aspx (cid:
) http://www.usa.gov/webcontent/technology/rss.shtml (cid:
) http://blogspace.com/rss/readers (cid:
) http://sharepoint.microsoft.com/pedia/pages/Conten
etails.aspx?Conten

IRS intranet sites and their content must be accessible. Federal and IRS policy requires it. The Information Resources Accessibility Program (IRAP) office in IT is responsible for setting IRS policy and standards for accessibility of intranet content. For more information about accessibility and Section
of the Reha- bilitation Act, contact IRAP (http://irap.web.irs.gov/) or the Alternate Media Center ( http://amc.enterprise.irs.gov). Two key resources from these offices include IRAP’s
Accessibility Checklists, and Web Services’ Accessibility Standards.

) IRS Web developers do not use on IRS systems, any proprietary code, such as can often be found for free from Internet sites, unless it has been approved concerning issues of implied agreements, licenses, and security. This policy, codified at IRM

, is based on IRS computer security policy and on a recent opinion provided by the office of Chief This restriction does not apply to any code initiated and completed within the IRS, or by contractors under IRS direction, if the code was developed within the limits stated herein. (
) Legal Review — Chief Counsel has issued an opinion (GLS-

) urging IRS employees to avoid the use of proprietary code since its use may be interpreted as having been acquired for the benefit of the IRS and therefore may establish an unacceptable agreement to conditions stated or implied in the code or by its developer. Only IRS employees and contractors who have delegated authority to obligate the Service to such an agreement may do so. If, however, certain code is not copyrighted and there are no or conditions for its use, employees may use this code, subject to security approval. For example, there are many Internet sites that provide information on the use of code and may provide samples of code to concepts of code use. (

) Security Approval and Enterprise Architecture Policy — Notwithstanding the legal limitations and exceptions noted above, IRS security policy the use on IRS systems of any code that has not been specifically reviewed and approved for use on our systems by MITS, Information Technology Security Architecture & Engineering (ITSAE) Office within Enterprise (ES). There is also IRS Enterprise Architecture policy on the use of open source code that must be considered. Web or applications developers who wish to use any third-party code on IRS systems must contact MITS to begin the review and approval process. (

) The recommendations outlined below should not be construed as official standards; rather it is a conglomeration of industry best practices and is only on provided as a starting point. The primary sources for these best practices listed below. IT has not yet provided official guidance regarding IT limitations such as bandwidth and server capabilities. It is highly recommended that file sizes be limited to no more than
MB. (

11.1.4.14 (02-17-2015) Use of Video/Audio on the Intranet

and Standards for Intranet Sites
(cid:
) Some employees may have computers without the necessary power to process a video (cid:
) Risk of adding to the auditory clutter in areas where workstations are located in common spaces, i.e., cubicles (cid:
) Employees are likely to tune in for a very short amount of time (cid:
) All video projects must be reviewed by the Servicewide Video Editorial Board (
) Comply with Section
standards. Refer to IRAP (http://irap.web.irs.gov/). audio or video the best way to get your message across? (

) Limited Use Recommended — Until IT can provide clear technical param- eters regarding the capabilities of the network and servers, the following use is recommended to deliver Corporate Messages: (cid:
) Deliver by executives or directors (cid:
) Length should be limited to about three minutes (cid:
) Topic must be relevant to all employees (cid:
) Limit frequency so the novelty doesn’t wear out (cid:
) Production values should be high quality (
) Help the Users — The following tips are taken from the Nielson Norman Group Guidelines “Designing Usable Intranets – Communication”
Provide the following Information about the video: a. Video’s length – write out the time like this –
minutes, and not like –
b. Date of the video c. Content summary d. Provide a transcript e. Information about the presenter if the presenter is new or unknown to audience

Warn users of potential technical issues and advise them of workarounds.EXAMPLE:Due to the large size of the video, we recommend saving file to your computer and viewing the video there. Directions to Right click on the link, select ‘Save Target As’. (
